review_title: A not so pay competitive and demanding job

2. Managers are very understanding when it comes to days off for student related needs

Low pay $10 an hour is just not competitive enough compared to other jobs currently available 
2. No benefits at all student Assistants do no get to park in staff lots
3. Traffic can get chaotic on campus 
4. Having to work 24 hours a week to make a rather decent paycheck just isn’t worth the time when Walmart starts at $15/hour
5. Will quickly realize that the amount of work expected and the pay doesn’t match

pros: Job was at the gym. It was pretty laid back but there were also stressful days depending on the people that came into the gym. I enjoyed getting to know my coworkers and all the students that came in. Everyday I came to work I was greeted with smiles and hugs from workers and gym regulars.
cons:
Towards the end the boss was hiring regulars and people that became friends with the staff. This caused some of the staff to turn into a clique. They were all nice but you could tell they had their own group hangouts outside of work. This didnt bother me that much. The worst thing was that once they became employees they didnt really talk to regulars coming into the gym. Instead they ignored people and talked to each other. The boss started realizing this so it is probably better now. The bad of this is now he probably wont hire friends who could have been good workers because of this.

The pay. Its not bad for a gym job but even managers have the same pay. There is no incentive to have more responsibility but you are expected to do so much more.

review_title: Heart is in the right place
job_title: Professional Writing Tutor in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: Everyone who works here is more than happy to lend a hand, or offer a suggestion, even if you're in the middle of a session or they are. It's a very welcoming environment for staff and students, and the management really lets you take the lead on things and set the pace in the workspace.
cons: Unfortunately, this soft-managing has repercussions, specifically when it comes to the student assistants and their understanding of what it is we "do." Many times they will seat us with a student who thinks they're getting their paper edited, only to have us tell them this is in fact the one service we do not offer.

review_title: GGC experiences very real growing pains.
pros: I will say the vast majority of the people I worked with were great.  The students were great to work with and most were enthusiastic about their education.  Faculty outside my department were easy to work with and communicate with.  There is a great deal of enthusiasm and excitement on the campus for its mission and goals.
cons: The area I worked in was not very supportive of family, children, or single parents.  Communication from further up the chain of command was slow to travel to others.  Where the department I worked in was going, what the plans were for getting there, how I fit into those plans, and communication on my performance were highly lacking.  Upper management left no recourse for filing grievances or seeing anything done to resolve issues.

pros:
Flexible with schedule
Networking prospects
Being involved with the school.
cons:
-Lots of red tape
-ignoring students workers needs in departments.
-too much focus on academics, they think anything not academics should get no budget or say.
-improper use of student tuitions.
-very disorganized, last minute events. Wasting students' funding.
-student workers are students too and should have a right to know what their money is being spent on.
- No evaluations on how student worker is doing.
- no response to misconduct

review_title: The culture is negative and most people regret ever coming.
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: The ability to help the students be successful.  They also have several restaurants on campus for your dining pleasure.  The campus is nice and well taken care of, but parking can be a challenge!!
cons: This organization can be very challenging and does not do a good job of making new hires feel welcome.  This is a CYA culture where new comers are dropped into the deep end of the pool and told to sink or swim.  Most sink because they don't get the help they need to be successful.   If you don't fit into their world, you will find work there and uphill battle!  During my tenure I  saw many great people leave or forced out because of the unhealthy competition and lack of true teamwork that exists.

job_title: IT Peer Tutor in Duluth, GA
pros:
As a peer tutor while you're studying, it helps you retain as well as learn new skills as you get to help students taking the same classes you've already taken, but with different professors. 

You make many friends in long run as you work with variety of people. 

It's a good opportunity to develop your interpersonal as well as communication skills. 

It helps you understand looking at the things from different eyes. 

Work-environment is really fun as everyone behaves friendly with you, regardless of your experience and expertise.
cons: It is demanding job as it requires you to be spontaneous. Sometimes you're dealing with problems you have never seen or dealt before.

review_title: A great place to work under the first president but declining due to new leadership.
pros: There's lots of flexibility to work on different things.  College is still young (less than ten years) so few entrenched ways of doing things that can't be changed.
cons: Where to begin?  GGC is chronically understaffed and when staff are added, it's often based on who has the ear of the new president.  In fact, that generally describes how resources are allocated at GGC.  Note: My "CEO" rating is based on the new president, not Dr. Kaufman who was amazing but has since moved on.

pros:
Flexibility in work time
Ability to make a career change if desired
Tuition assistance for extending your education
The college has a good core mission and values. They operate much like a start-up which is refreshing to see for a college where things can be beaten down by bureaucracy.
cons:
The salaries aren't what you'd make in any corporate setting
Raises are few and far between unless you change titles
The college is very new, so some procedures that you may be used to may not exist yet.

review_title: Beware they myriad of scams, lies and unfair treatment of employees
pros: The professors, program offerings,  flexibility and affordability
cons:
Leadership, Discrimination, Salary, Nepotism 
There is so much to say about my experiences and my colleagues perspectives that there isn't enough space to articulate it all. I will start with this. Positions have been created for those who don't have experience but know people at the college and may have a spouse that work here. These folks are given carte blanche when different standards are expected of others. Need I say more?
Discrimination- I have heard and learned that the treatment of minorities is different in the South. While discrimination is wide spread, this institution takes the cake. I know Black folk that work here with Master's that hold administrative positions and are well qualified for other opportunities. However, if you "drink the koolaid" as they say, you may obtain a position. But at what cost? Ethics, values, and the mission that are stated on marketing materials are not shared and embraced by the leadership team. GGC is corrupt.
Salary-they do not give raises. Leadership are the only folks eligible for raises. Six figure salaries for the executive/leadership team, but other employees in many cases are underemployed.
An alumni told me that her experience as a student was more positive than her experience working here and it's concerning because she hoped her alma mater stood above the fray. The reputation of the culture here is not good. Look at the surveys. You will see that what little I'm sharing here is felt by many. During my first year 8 people quit in my department. HR does not do anything to support employees concerns, even when evidence based. And if you share any negative experiences with HR you will be black balled.

pros:
Decent IT management
Looks for new software/hardware to better suit needs of teachers
Pretty fair in terms of job responsibilities
cons:
Favoritism
Lots of office politics
Co-workers hired are not exactly filtered out, mostly lazy (not talking about the full-time staff)

pros:
You are the difference between a students good college experience or bad college experience.

cons:
Supervisors are alllll micromanagers for the most part 
They promote people who don’t know what they are doing 
Most people are on a power trip 
Benefits suck
Ungrateful 
Pay Sucks if you’re not at the top
